properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: local snowfall possibly reaching 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 60 km/h causing blowing snow. Locations: Inverness County - south of Mabou, Victoria county, Pictou and Antigonish counties, and Kings county, Prince Edward Island. Time frame: until late this afternoon or early this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T00:59:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T14:23:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2745457624.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills continues. Wind chill values have moderated in a few locations this morning, however are once again expected to return to the minus 45 to minus 50 range across portions of northern Saskatchewan tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T08:52:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T16:53:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0447833712.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall amounts: up to 10 cm in snow squalls. Location: Corner Brook to Port aux Basques. Time span: until this afternoon. Remarks: Onshore flurries and occasional snow squalls are expected to persist until this afternoon. Poor visibilities can be expected within the snow squalls. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Westerly winds will reach 90 kilometres per hour today. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 10 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected over these regions by Tuesday morning. In addition, flurries at times heavy accompanied by blowing snow are also possible as the cold front passes tonight. Visibilities will be reduced to near zero in blowing snow after more sustained snow begins over these regions. As a result, temperatures will drop rapidly after its passage. Conditions should gradually improve late in the night, however additional snowfall is expected during the day and evening on Monday. Travel conditions could be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T12:14:44-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Monday. Snow associated with an approaching Colorado Low will move into portions of northeastern Ontario Monday morning or early afternoon and persist into Monday night. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely by late Monday night. Travel conditions are likely to be poor at times across the area. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely Monday. Precipitation associated with an approaching Colorado Low will move into portions of northeastern Ontario Monday morning or early afternoon. Several hours of freezing rain are possible in some areas from Monday afternoon into the evening. At this point, the greatest threat of freezing rain will likely be from Elliot Lake towards Sudbury and areas north of the city of North Bay. Freezing warnings may be issued for some areas as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T12:15:31-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow ending this evening. More snow on the way for Monday. Snow will taper off early this evening over portions of northeastern Ontario. However, snow will intensify Monday morning or early afternoon as a Colorado Low approaches the area. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are likely by the time the snow tapers of late Monday night. Travel conditions are likely to be poor at times across the area. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T12:27:23-00:00

Area: Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues today. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are likely, with a few pockets of 10 to 15 cm possible especially near the Quebec border. In addition to today's snowfall, there is a risk of a brief but intense snow squall as a sharp Arctic cold front moves through. Visibility may suddenly drop to near zero with this snow squall. Snow squall watches and warnings may be issued if necessary. Road conditions are likely to be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. The snow may taper off for several hours tonight in the wake of the cold front, However, more snow with additional accumulation is expected Monday as a disturbance from the Midwestern States crosses Northeastern Ontario. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T03:59:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T16:20:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0790551981.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 20 centimetres of snow is expected over these regions through Sunday evening. Flurries at times heavy and blowing snow are also possible as the cold front moves through in the second half of the day, potentially giving significantly reduced visibilities. Temperatures will also drop rapidly in its wake. Conditions are expected to gradually improve overnight Sunday night; however, additional snowfall accumulations are expected during the day on Monday. Travel conditions could be poor at times. Motorists are urged to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 40 to 80 mm, with the highest amounts falling over the higher terrain of the Long Range Mountains and inland of the Southwest Coast. Maximum wind gusts: southerly at 80 to 100 km/h, with the highest gusts along the coast. Locations: Gros Morne, Cornerbrook, Bay St. George, Port aux Basques and Burgeo - Ramea. Time span: Monday night through Wednesday. Remarks: Rain will begin Monday night then become heavy, at times, Tuesday with strong southerly winds. The wind and rain will become less intense Tuesday night before transitioning to flurries on Wednesday. In addition, the strong winds and heavy rainfall will result in snowmelt over higher elevation which may increase the potential for localized flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-09T11:25:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T19:26:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1887542391.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A weak disturbance crossing northern Yukon is giving strong east winds of 50 km/h gusting to 70 near the Richardson Mountains and result in reduced visibility in blowing snow. Winds will ease this afternoon and conditions will improve. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T01:54:46-00:00

Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain is forecast for Monday. The snow will affect these regions tonight, and will leave between 5 and 10 centimetres of snow before changing to freezing rain late Monday. Freezing precipitation accumulations of 2 to 4 millimetres are expected over these areas. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Temperatures in the minus thirties combined with northwest winds of 15 km/h will result in extreme wind chills near the warning threshold of -45 over far northern Manitoba overnight. Conditions should moderate slightly Monday, but extreme wind chills will likely return Monday night and persist into Tuesday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T13:18:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T21:19:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3092757064.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A disturbance tracking northward into Foxe Basin will bring increasing easterly winds into the Pangnirtung region overnight. Light easterly winds early this evening will gradually increase tonight with wind gusts up to 70 km/h by morning. The strongest winds are expected Monday with easterly gusts to 90 km/h or higher possible long with some blowing snow. Winds are expected to diminish Tuesday evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

Northerly winds of 50 to 60 km/h will give blizzard conditions tonight and Monday with gradual improvement in visibilities expected late Tuesday as winds slowly diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures are forecast to fall rapidly this evening to well below freezing due the passage of an Arctic cold front. Ponding water, slush, and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops. As of 5:00 P.M. EST the cold front has just passed Chapleau. At 8:00 P.M. EST the cold front will be near Kirkland Lake. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T05:24:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T22:05:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3461053509.2019
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake, Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning Ended
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squall conditions are no longer expected. ###

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong westerly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero on Monday. A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow causing widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-09T12:08:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-08T20:09:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2427464954.2019
Area: Salluit, Kangiqsujuaq - Raglan Lake, Kangirsuk
properties.Author: Environment Canada
